body: I've opened an issue to address our swagger gaps (see #270). There are a number of deficiencies I know about.

I propose the following plan to implement this support.   This plan makes no changes to the API but will introduce a new flag in the CLI.

The basic strategy is that each new version of a runtime is identified by a unique string, and all runtime versions are peers -- there is no hierarchy.    So in particular, we currently have runtimes named "nodejs", "swift", and "docker" (and "python" when we handle the PR).

Step 1 will be to simply introduce a new runtime "swift3" which is logically a peer of all the other variants.
This requires no API change.

Step 2 will be to add a -type flag to wsk action create.   So wsk action create x.swift will create a "swift" action, but wsk action create -type "swift3" x.swift creates a "swift3" action.

That's basically it for the short term, and will satisfy our short term needs (modulo UI support).

In the medium term, we would rename our current runtimes to "nodejs0.12.9", "swift2.2", and "python3.3" (or whatever),   and then define aliases such as "nodejs" -> latest version of nodejs we support.    So "nodejs" would change it's meaning to mean "the latest version supported in the system".

That's basically it.    Please comment if you have an opinion.

Fine with me but to confirm.....

In both the short-term and medium-term of the proposal, the invoker will pull a distinct image from our registry for each runtime (or runtime + version).  The use of dockerhub registry for creating our images is a build-time step detail for how things get into our registry.

+1 as it's the most predictable approach.

Need to keep in mind semantic versioning though. In which granularity do we update? That's probably dependent on the runtime itself. 
- **node.js < 0** for example i would nail them to the minor version (nodejs0.12 for example).
- **node.js > 4** though, i'ld go for just major version (nodejs4, nodejs5, nodejs6)

A parseable naming-approach would be good aswell. For example we could follow docker's `:tag` approach to then have `nodejs:4`, `nodejs:5` and so on, while `nodejs:latest` would be a placeholder for the latest and greatest.
fixed.
FYI: a build of node6 it's out and will become LTS in Oct/2016

The short-term solution is fine with me.

We will eventually have the discussion about supported packages on the runtime though.
Also keep in mind that we will have versions on the packages, too. So you can have the same node version but with different versions of express, request or other npm packages.

On CloudFoundry we have the notion of package.json descriptors that pull the required packages upfront. We could do similar things in a "bootstrapping" phase of a user container that does not get charged by time (msec), maybe only a fixed value per activation itself. Of course that means the first time the action is run you get a longer waiting period.

swift samples to develop:
- [ ] echo.swift
- [ ] greeting.swift
- [ ] wc.swift

Just to confirm, as a stop-gap I'm looking into installing KituraNet as a framework to do network calls for Swift actions.  I already have an image for Swift 3.

Hopefully, Foundation implementation will catch up soon.

@paulcastro the stop-gap is for swift 2? I think we should just go forward with Swift 3 if you already have it ready and not bother with Swift 2, team can use a docker image for develop the new swift actions

I think we should will skip [github/webhook.swift](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/catalog/github/webhook.js) for now.
Since it's just a provider to setup the trigger to be invoke via webhook, and not an example the user will copy and modify to adjust to his need.
What others think?

I recommend we do not do this.   My reasons are twofold: 1) I don't want to have 2 weather action implementations to maintain, and 2) it will be a long time before Swift supports networking needed to implement this.

I recommend closing as "won't fix".

I recommend we do not do this.   My reasons are twofold: 1) I don't want to have 2 watson implementations to maintain, and 2) it will be a long time before Swift supports networking needed to implement this.

I recommend closing as "won't fix".

I recommend we do not do this.   My reasons are twofold: 1) I don't want to have 2 slack  implementations to maintain, and 2) it will be a long time before Swift supports networking needed to implement this.

I recommend closing as "won't fix".
Since these are small, self-contained actions, I think it's reasonable to implement them in swift as tutorial examples.
I believe the duration is end - start, both of which are present above.

1) both start and end should be in a human-readable format
2) we should include a field on duration, so users don't have to calculate it manually

The stopgap requires Swift 3, but that version of Swift does not have stable APIs yet.  I'd recommend keeping Swift 2 as our default and only moving to Swift 3 when it is stable.  We can deploy Swift 3 as an experimental runtime.
There's a difference between what we record and then how/what we make easier for the user to consume. This can be solved entirely in the CLI for example to mimic the UI.

i think it's cumbersome for api clients having to do the math by themselves. we'll need to calculate the duration anyway server-side, for audit and billing purposes, so should expose that record via the api.

additionally, implementing it in the various clients one by one is likely going to result in inconsistencies.
I've updated the Docker container in #273 to load lib dispatch and KituraNet.  The python proxy still needs to be updated

Here is what it fixed it for me:

```
$ sudo python -m pip install --upgrade --force setuptools
$ sudo python -m pip install --upgrade --force pip
```
@nauerz-ibm `wsk property  get --cliversion` please.
@nauerz-ibm This seems like a Vagrant issue specific to your Windows machine, see https://www.virtualbox.org/ticket/15019.  The instructions assume you can run a Vagrant machine on your native host.

Did you try this tip from the docs? 

**Tip:** By default, each docker command will timeout after 240 seconds (4 minutes). If you're on a really slow connection, this might be too short. You can modify the timeout value in docker.gradle as needed.

This issue is not specific to openwhisk. We don't document how to upgrade the CLI from an external source. We are transitioning to a go CLI in #238 and I am inclined to close this as won't fix in openwhisk.

@starpit perhaps a troubleshooting tip is useful in CLI configuration page from the UI.
Assuming you are running against a local deployment, your deployment is actually not up. This may be a duplicate of https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/31#issuecomment-190015793.

That is correct.
@markusthoemmes said that a restart is necessary after the above mentioned steps - and indeed the restart helped to circumvent some initial issues. So if it is required we should update the doc.

I just tried rerunning the process by over and over again running ant build - that is what the documentation suggests, too:

> Tip: Since the first build takes some time, it is not uncommon for some step to fail if there's a network hiccup or other interruption of some kind. If this happens you may see a Build FAILED message that suggests a Docker operation timed out. You can simply try ant build again and it will mostly pick up where it left off. This should only be an issue the very first time you build -- subsequent builds do far less network activity thanks to Docker caching.

Even though that finally worked and even though your proposal may help a bit, too, I think we need to improve to provide a much better user-experience (I know you guys are working hard... maybe this is something Matt & team can start working on asap)...

Indeed this looks like the same issue.
What I wonder is: Why is that happening even though I followed the instructions step by step?

Proposal: Let me see if I can reproduce the issue tomorrow after having properly cleaned-up everything. Maybe I tried too many different things finally leading to a totally screwed system.

I am fine with closing as this indeed seems to be a python/pip related thing; I found the answer on stackoverflow where people ended-up in similar scenarios not having anything to do with OW at all.

A troubleshooting tip might nevertheless be good.

I've already cleaned-up my previous system.
But I used the latest version (downloaded it yesterday) from openwhisk/bin.
Will try again tomorrow after having cleaned-up everything; will report the results here.


couple of thoughts:
- all samples which are installed by default should have adequate tests.
- we probably don't need all of these.   Some (helloAsync, printParams, wcbin?) can probably be deleted instead.

`wcbin` is poorly named - it's an example of an action calling another action using a blocking invoke.
`countdown` shouldn't be in the catalog as is because is it not parametric to the namespace (see https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/80#issuecomment-206634585).

Took out the 443. I will add a forecast parameter for all API options:
1.GET /api/weather/v2/geocode/forecast/daily/10day
Returns a daily 10-day forecast, for a geolocation, in the provided units of measure

2.GET /api/weather/v2/geocode/forecast/hourly/24hour
Returns an hourly 2-day forecast, for a geolocation, in the provided units of measure

3.GET /api/weather/v2/geocode/observations/current
Returns the current weather conditions, for a geolocation, in the provided units of measure

4.GET /api/weather/v2/geocode/observations/timeseries/24hour
Returns both the current observations and up to 24 hours of past observations, from the current date and time, for a geolocation, in the provided units of measure
Do we want to keep `curl.js`?
as an example of calling a "process"? But could use a better example than curl.

one of the drivers for this is that the UI will now show the samples list front and center. so having a compelling list will become important pretty soon.

to me, "compelling" means:

1) high orthogonality; we have several very similar actions
2) super easy to use; no mystery API key
3) at least two languages?
4) at least some have to be not simple utility routines

hopefully something better than this, but in this spirit: 

Hello World in Javascript
Hello World in Swift
Weather Forecast
Programmatic API: Calling a non-OpenWhisk API
Sequencing: Integrating an OpenWhisk API
Rules: Periodic Weather Forecast
PG 436 passed now.

It looks like we need to do some clean up
- keep hello.js (Hello World in Javascript)
- keep hello.swift (Hello World in Swift) and installed it and add testing, this is related to #188 that @bjustin-ibm is looking into
- weather.js or yahooWeather.js . Create new sample for js only (i.e. no swift) for weather forecast using yahoo plubic api that doesn't require api key same code as in the docs here https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/actions.md#using-actions-to-call-an-external-api. This ones is to show how to call an external API in the docs currently
- delete helloAsync.js 
- delete printParams.js
- delete wcbin.js
- rename curl.js (Shows how to use whisk.aysnc and whisk.done) Currently calls background process, according to @rabbah https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/302#issuecomment-216378984 we need to use a better process than curl in. maybe sleep?. Only js (i.e. no swift) 
- countdown.js (Show how to use whisk.invoke() from inside an action) improve with new implementation from @rabbah https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/80#issuecomment-206634585. Add testing for it. Only for js (i.e. no swift) 

@starpit let's have a chat on the following 3
- Programmatic API: Calling a non-OpenWhisk API
  (Does the action calling yahoo weather api covers, or you mean something else?)
- Sequencing: Integrating an OpenWhisk API
  It looks like there are two concepts here. you want a sample with action sequence for example 2 actions, action 1 output is the input to action 2?
  Or an action that programmatically creates two actions, and  a sequence with those actions using the whisk client sdk inside a nodejs action?
- Rules: Periodic Weather Forecast
  It looks like there are two concepts here. you want to show the concept of a rule using alarm and yahoo weather, we need to be careful as not hitting the rate limit on the yahoo weather public api with no api key. It would be kind of tricky to get a simple sample to work out of the box.
  Maybe we can show an action that shows how to use whisk.trigger() and there is a rule that comes in samples to listen to the trigger and invokes the forecast.

I feel like as samples (code we show to the customer to instruct them in the ways of OpenWhisk) a lot of these are so simple as to not provide much educational value.  For example, the differences between Hello, Echo, and WordCount do not provide _any_ clarity on what can be done by running this code on OpenWhisk - they are really just showing some very trivial things that can be done with the Swift language on any platform.

If the purpose of these samples is to teach the customer useful things they need to know about OpenWhisk, then I think one very simple Hello action would be appropriate. This shows them the basic structure of a Whisk action in Swift.  Beyond that, we probably want to start showing them samples that show the unique capabilities of OpenWhisk like... invoking other actions, firing triggers, etc.

I realize that we don't currently have a `whisk` backend object that does these things in the same way that is available on, say, the Node.JS runtime, but maybe we should focus on creating that so we can implement more educational samples.

Thoughts?

@sjfink I know you had reservations about exposing Kitura to the customer, but if we encapsulated use of Kitura to the implementation of functions like `invoke()` and `fireTrigger()` inside a `whisk` object that we make available to the customer's Swift code, then the customer will never know or care how it works under the hood.

@bjustin-ibm I remove some actions that we are not going to implement based on discussion from #302 
- countdown.swift
  We don't have whisk library for whisk.invoke
- curl.swift
  We don't have whis.done or whisk.async
- helloAsync.swift
  We are going to delete helloAync.js
- printParams.swift
  We are going to delete printParams.js
- wcbin.swift
  We are going to delete wcbin.js

I agree with https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/188#issuecomment-216608142 we can start  by using Kitura-Net under the hood, developer doesn't need to know anything about the implementation, to invoke an action or fire a trigger from inside swift, it's just a whisk context object with these methods attached. 
We can replace Kitura-Net with something else in the future and maintain the API on the whisk context object.

I predict you'll find the kitura.net support is much more work and much uglier than you anticipate.   @paulcastro is implementing some user actions using kitura -- let's wait till we see these before we make any decisions.

I have a commit in my fork of openwhisk in branch "kituraRuntime" that has one example.  [catalog/samples/helloSwift3.swift](https://github.com/paulcastro/openwhisk/blob/kituraRuntime/catalog/samples/helloSwift3.swift).  It uses KituraNet to make a "get" call and GCD to manage the async callback.  There are other patterns you could use in GCD that "may" work, depending on GCD implementation in Linux.

for this PR, I'm just curios

Did run some tests on travis, findings so far:
- in theory, you can install virtualbox and vagrant on the travis container.
- you need to put these in travis.yml:

```
  - sudo apt-get install -y linux-headers-$(uname -r)
  - sudo apt-get install dkms -y
  - wget http://download.virtualbox.org/virtualbox/5.0.20/virtualbox-5.0_5.0.20-106931~Ubuntu~trusty_amd64.deb
  - sudo dpkg -i virtualbox-5.0_5.0.20-106931~Ubuntu~trusty_amd64.deb
  - sudo wget -nv https://releases.hashicorp.com/vagrant/1.8.1/vagrant_1.8.1_x86_64.deb
  - sudo dpkg -i vagrant_1.8.1_x86_64.deb
```
- problem A: travis timeout is going to bite us. the vagrant download takes about 25 mins. timeout is 50 mins. without forking this into a separate travis build, it is not going to work.
- problem B: our vagrant box requires a GUI (reasons beyond me) which we don't have on a build machine.
- problem C: we probably don't want to test the vagrant image every time we do a commit. the travis build should be as quick as possible to allow fast development. I don't know of any possibility to schedule travis builds on a per-day basis.

alternative solution: move this issue to our own build env and do it with jenkins.
@jeremiaswerner @markusthoemmes @sjfink @rabbah your thoughts?
Why are we going back?

> problem B: our vagrant box requires a GUI (reasons beyond me) which we don't have on a build machine.

really? the gui is optional and not installed by default.

i might be confusing this with something else - can you clarify.
Missing a CLI test to run with `--type swift3`?

@rabbah because we don't have some internal docker daemons and docker clients still on older dockers which would cause incompatibility and would break the internal pipeline. we will remove the flag once we are all set with docker 1.11. (the flag is deprecated for 1.11 and will be removed with 1.12)

about problem B: No GUI is required, I'm using vagrant with no GUI.

I think using our jenkins will be the solution to test vagrant setup based on problem A and C
@domdom82 can you take this one?

brainstorm:   we have in my lab Mac Minis we can use as we like.

How about a "normal" jenkins build that runs the vagrant build on a MacOS slave?
We should look at Cloud Foundry and Heroku build packs for inspiration.

Overall it looks sensible to me. Rebasing will make it dramatically easier to review the next iteration (no more swiftAction being modified then reverted etc.). As Rodric points out, we need CLI tests, and we need tests somewhere that exercise the new features (either as CLI tests or as container tests). Finally I'm personally in favor of calling the CLI flag `--kind` since that's already the name of the field in the JSON object.

@csantanapr did you patch the Vagrantfile?

```
   vb.gui = true
```

seems pretty hard-coded to me. Does it work ootb if you do not have a GUI? Did you set it to false on your env?
+1 on --kind

This is a subject that intrigues me, a build pack approach was suggested "out-of-the-blue" at the CF meetup last week.  I have a follow-up scheduled with the person from Altoros, an IBM partner company.
This is work I think my team would like to champion; we need to solicit external requirements.
Kind it is.

Ah - I am sure we can make this optional.
I was thinking of the `ubuntu-desktop.sh` - so for that to work, gui must be true, but we don't need to turn on the gui if the common case is not to use a deskop in the vagrant machine.
I would agree. The only benefit you get is when used in conjunction with ubuntu-desktop.

@rabbah yes. the readme still applies as it suggests to run git clone with no directory param, hence always creating an "openwhisk" directory. the PR just gives you the freedom to choose another dir to clone into.

@domdom82 I would leave vb.gui = true for users not have to change it if they want GUI, this way users just need to run the ubuntu-desktop script

I would assume that having vb.gui in jenkins slave would just be ignore and work, if you tested and it doesn't work then I think we just need to flip it to false dynamically when running the build in jenkins
It can be factored so that it can be overridden is the point - with a default of true to preserve current behavior. This is how `shared` works.

we could make

```
GUI = ENV['VAGRANT_GUI'] || true 
```

added option to disable GUI using

```
VB_GUI=false vagrant up
```

should we document this in readme? where?
doc in the readme as a note, for headless systems that don't support GUI
